ADA Pledges Support
Wally Orlinsky, an undergrad
student at Hopkins, apprised
the members of Americans for
Democratic Action of the situation here at Hopkins at their
meeting on Monday evening. According to Orlinsky, the group
was very enthusiastic about the
actions being 'taken at Hopkins.
They were ready to pass endorsement of actions such as picketing, boycotts, etc. on the spot. At
the meeting Judge Watts presented a motion to adopt a resolution supporting any possible
action on the part of Hopkins
students. They are ready to pass
it at any time. The support of
the Congress of Racial Equality
was also enlisted at the same
time.
A few students expressed outright approval of discrimination
and racial segregation. Some
stated that they would rather not
support or involve themselves in
any movement. Still others would
make no comment. A great many
of the students who advocated
definite action regretted that
they were unable to participate
because of a lack of time and
the rapidly approaching final
exams.

Ginsberg's action.

Council's role as an outlet for undergraduate opinion to
disagree vehemently with Ginsberg's unjudicious action.
In cases where a trial or hearing is being held, where
personal reputation may be harmed, such .policy. cannot
be questioned. But when the topic is one which concerns
all undergraduates, such action is censurable.

Student Council has the right to a closeil meeting, but
we earnestly hope that in the future more discretion will
